16.10.text:
INTERVIEWER: The poet Roland
Barthes talks about the amorous

23.29.text:
this intersubjective
ecstasy that you enter

36.77.text:
Sort of sexually enabled,
technologically mediated,

41.10.text:
Buddhist space where
two become one.

43.73.text:
I keep bringing back term
intersubjective, ecstasy.

46.63.text: Why do we love to cuddle?

48.06.text:
Why do we love to give each
other baby names and treat

51.24.text:
each other like
we're little children

53.11.text:
and create kind of womb-like
spaces of comfort and divinity

56.56.text:
for one another where we can
be as gods outside of time,

60.73.text:
temporarily stepping off
that people mover that's

63.90.text:
carrying everyone else towards
death, as Alan Harrington says?

68.31.text:
We're trying to find
escapes from the despair.

72.51.text:
Together we are creating
a shared universe

75.45.text:
where we can float above
the clouds of entropy.

82.17.text: That is what love is about.

83.37.text:
It's about saving
ourselves from mortality.

87.19.text:
We are the gods with anuses,
as Ernest Becker says.

90.64.text:
And we do everything we can to
deny our own creaturely-ness,

94.55.text:
to deny our own decay,
to deny all you despair.

98.54.text:
Can you blame us for squeezing
so tightly around one another?

102.13.text:
Can you blame us for wanting
to listen to beautiful music

106.88.text:
Can you blame us for
wanting to seek out

109.20.text:
comfort in each other's
cold soul space and to say,

113.30.text:
please tell me you
will not leave me,

124.65.text:
And they say, oh,
we're co-dependent.

130.09.text:
It's what all the psychedelic
explorers have told us.
